text:
29 Horatio Street, north side between West 4th Street and Hudson showing former site of P.S. 124.

Board of Education, N.Y.C.

1920.

16-18 Horatio Street, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Eighth Ave. Also shown is 56-60 Eighth Ave., at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of Horatio Street. The corner building "Vetts Hotel", bears Nos. 18 Horatio, and 60 Eighth Ave.

March 29, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Eighth Avenue, south from Jane Street to Abingdon Square. On the right is the west frontage that extends to W. 12th Street. Upon the latter was erected (1931) the modern 20-story apartment house, No. 299 W. 12th Street. View 2 is limited to this block and its new structure. On the right is south side of Jane Street extending westward to Hudson Street.

May 30, 1929
March 9, 1933

P. L. Sperr

Eighth Avenue, south from Jane Street to Abingdon Square. On the right is the west frontage that extends to W. 12th Street. Upon the latter was erected (1931) the modern 20-story apartment house, No. 299 W. 12th Street. View 2 is limited to this block and its new structure. On the right is south side of Jane Street extending westward to Hudson Street.

May 30, 1929
March 9, 1933

P. L. Sperr

Eighth Avenue, north from W. 4th Street (left, and upon which appears a view from Horatio to 13th Street), showing in the background the New York Port Authority Building and the Trust Co. Building on opposite sides of this thoroughfare. View No. 2 emphasizes the latter and is in a north eastward direction.
A peculiarity of the low foreground structures is that those to the left of the bend bear Nos. 1 and 3 Horatio Street, extending to 4th Street and those to the right, bear No's 51 to 63 Eighth Avenue, proceeding to 13th Street.

July 31, 1938.
Views 1 and 2

P.L. Sperr

(3)

A view limited to the foreground of View 2, showing solely that irregular triangular block between Horatio and W. 13th Streets. At the left is the termination of West 4th Street.

January 22, 1929

P. L. Sperr

Eighth Avenue, north from W. 4th Street (left, and upon which appears a view from Horatio to 13th Street), showing in the background the New York Port Authority Building and the Trust Co. Building on opposite sides of this thoroughfare. View No. 2 emphasizes the latter and is in a north eastward direction.
A peculiarity of the low foreground structures is that those to the left of the bend bear Nos. 1 and 3 Horatio Street, extending to 4th Street and those to the right, bear No's 51 to 63 Eighth Avenue, proceeding to 13th Street.

July 31, 1938.
Views 1 and 2

P.L. Sperr

(3)

A view limited to the foreground of View 2, showing solely that irregular triangular block between Horatio and W. 13th Streets. At the left is the termination of West 4th Street.

P. L. Sperr

Building on opposite sides of this thoroughfare. View No. 2 emphasizes the latter and is in a north eastward direction.
A peculiarity of the low foreground structures is that those to the left of the bend bear Nos. 1 and 3 Horatio Street, extending to 4th Street and those to the right, bear No's 51 to 63 Eighth Avenue, proceeding to 13th Street.

Views 1 and 2

P.L. Sperr

(3)

A view limited to the foreground of View 2, showing solely that irregular triangular block between Horatio and W. 13th Streets. At the left is the termination of West 4th Street.

January 22, 1929

P. L. Sperr

16, 14, 10-8 Horatio Street, south side, east of and from Eighth Avenue. No. 10-8 is the Chapel of the Comforter (Protestant Episcopal). May 27, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

Eighth Avenue, east side, at Jane Street and north to Horatio Street.
March 10, 1933.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

Eighth Avenue, west side, north from 4th Street.
March 9, 1933.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

(2)
Eighth Avenue, west side, north from 4th Street.
March 9, 1933.

March 9, 1933.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

328-330 West 4th Street at S.W. corner of Jane Street, showing Eighth Avenue where the N.W. corner would otherwise have been. 328 is the little one-story house adjoining the corner. March 16, 1933. P.L. Sperr.

4th Street, east side, from Jane to 12th Streets, inclusive, seen from Eighth Avenue and 4th Streets.
The house on the S.E. corner of Jane Street, which used to be wooden with a stone front, has been rebuilt since 1930.
March 12, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Jane Street, east from Eighth Avenue.
March 12, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

30 to 2 Jane Street, south side, from east of 4th Street and Eighth Avenue to and including Greenwich Avenue, and showing 102-98 Greenwich Avenue.

July 7, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Nos. 16 and 18 (the 2 five-story tenements adjoining the garage) (No. 10-14) after an ownership of 60 years by the Edward Brown Estate have been sold and will be extensively altered according to the New York Times of April 12, 1938.

31, 29, 27, 25-21, 19 Jane Street, north side, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of 4th (formerly Asylum) Street. No. 27 is a frame house.

March 9, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Horatio Street, east from Eighth, to and including Greenwich Aves. Also shown (across Jackson Square), are Nos. 253-237 West 13th Street, north side, east of Greenwich Ave. Prominent building (No. 253), is a power house for the Municipal Eighth Ave. Subway. Adjoining same, is the Jackson Square Branch of the New York Public Library.

June 20, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

Horatio Street, east from Eighth, to and including Greenwich Aves. Also shown (across Jackson Square), are Nos. 253-237 West 13th Street, north side, east of Greenwich Ave. Prominent building (No. 253), is a power house for the Municipal Eighth Ave. Subway. Adjoining same, is the Jackson Square Branch of the New York Public Library.

June 20, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

Eighth Avenue, south from Horatio Street, showing mainly the easterly side of same. The photographer is viewing towards Abingdon Square where the dominant 16-story apartment house appears. This bears No. 20 Abingdon Square and is at the S. E. corner of W. 12th Street.

Returning to the foreground one observes the diagonal sweep of W. 4th Street across the Avenue, this is on right and running to the left center. This leaves a triangular block in the center, the apex of which touches upon Jane Street. The latter, though not seen, runs in a horizontal plane across the midground and is obstructed from view by the buildings at the right and left.

P. L. Sperr

April 9, 1940
